title: Complex Sentences — Combining Ideas with Subordinating Conjunctions
description: Students advance their grammar skills by learning to construct complex sentences using subordinating conjunctions. They explore how dependent and independent clauses work together to express nuanced relationships between ideas.
instructions:
1. Review simple and compound sentences from previous weeks.
2. Introduce complex sentences: an independent clause joined with a dependent clause.
3. Define subordinating conjunctions: because, although, when, if, since, while, after, before.
4. Model how subordinating conjunctions show relationships: cause, contrast, time, condition.
5. Practice identifying independent and dependent clauses in sample sentences.
6. Demonstrate placing the dependent clause at the beginning vs. end of a sentence.
7. Discuss comma rules: comma after a leading dependent clause, no comma when it follows.
8. Students combine simple sentences into complex sentences using various conjunctions.
9. Apply complex sentences to a paragraph about ancient Greece.
10. Peer review for correct clause structure and punctuation.

slides.setup_instructions: Print the subordinating conjunctions chart organized by relationship type. Prepare sentence combining cards with pairs of simple sentences to combine. Have grammar reference guides available.

slides.text: A simple sentence has one independent clause: 'Athens was a powerful city.' A compound sentence joins two independent clauses: 'Athens was powerful, and Sparta was strong.' A COMPLEX sentence joins an independent clause with a dependent clause: 'Although Sparta was strong, Athens led in philosophy and art.'

Subordinating conjunctions create dependent clauses and show relationships between ideas. CAUSE: because, since. CONTRAST: although, even though, while. TIME: when, after, before, until. CONDITION: if, unless. Each conjunction signals a specific logical connection.

Clause placement matters for emphasis. Leading dependent clause: 'Because Athens valued education, it produced great philosophers.' The dependent clause sets context. Trailing: 'Athens produced great philosophers because it valued education.' The independent clause gets emphasis. Both are correct; choose based on what you want to stress.

Comma rule: When the dependent clause comes FIRST, use a comma before the independent clause. 'Although Sparta had a stronger army, Athens had a stronger navy.' When the independent clause comes first, no comma is needed. 'Athens had a stronger navy although Sparta had a stronger army.'

slides.prompt: Practice complex sentences: (1) Combine 10 pairs of simple sentences into complex sentences using different subordinating conjunctions. (2) Write each combined sentence two ways: dependent clause first, then independent clause first. (3) Underline the dependent clause in blue and the independent clause in red. (4) Write a paragraph about ancient Greece using at least 5 complex sentences with varied conjunctions.

slides.text: Complex sentences allow you to express sophisticated relationships between ideas — cause and effect, contrast, conditions, and time sequences. They are the tool that elevates your writing from a list of simple facts to connected, flowing arguments.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify independent and dependent clauses, use subordinating conjunctions correctly, apply comma rules for complex sentences, and write varied complex sentences?

parent_notes: Complex sentences are a significant grammar milestone. They allow children to express nuanced thinking — cause and effect, exceptions, conditions — that simple sentences cannot capture. The comma rule (comma after a leading dependent clause) is one of the most practical punctuation rules in English. Practice by asking your child to combine ideas in conversation using 'although,' 'because,' and 'when.'

title: Multiplication Review — Multi-Digit Multiplication Strategies
description: Students strengthen their multiplication skills with multi-digit problems using the standard algorithm, partial products, and estimation. They apply multiplication to real-world problems involving large numbers from ancient civilizations.
instructions:
1. Review multiplication facts and identify any gaps.
2. Model the standard algorithm for multi-digit multiplication.
3. Introduce partial products as an alternative strategy.
4. Compare methods: when is each most efficient?
5. Practice estimating products before calculating exact answers.
6. Apply multiplication to area and perimeter problems.
7. Solve word problems using ancient Greek contexts: army sizes, building dimensions.
8. Students complete a timed multiplication fluency check.
9. Work through multi-step problems requiring multiplication and addition.
10. Challenge: multiply three-digit by two-digit numbers.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare multiplication practice worksheets at varying difficulty levels. Have grid paper available for the partial products method. Print multiplication reference charts for students who need support.

slides.text: The standard algorithm works right to left: multiply by the ones digit, then the tens digit, then add. For 47 x 36: first calculate 47 x 6 = 282, then 47 x 30 = 1,410, then add: 282 + 1,410 = 1,692. Each step must be precise.

Partial products break multiplication into parts: 47 x 36 = (40 x 30) + (40 x 6) + (7 x 30) + (7 x 6) = 1,200 + 240 + 210 + 42 = 1,692. This method shows WHY multiplication works and helps you check your standard algorithm answer.

Always ESTIMATE before calculating. For 47 x 36, estimate: 50 x 40 = 2,000. Your exact answer should be close to this. If you get 16,920 or 169, you know something is wrong. Estimation is your error detector.

Ancient Greeks used multiplication for real purposes: The Parthenon is about 228 feet long and 101 feet wide. The area is 228 x 101 = 23,028 square feet. A Greek army of 34 units with 128 soldiers each had 34 x 128 = 4,352 soldiers. Mathematics served civilization.

slides.prompt: Multiplication mastery: (1) Complete 10 multi-digit problems using the standard algorithm. Estimate first, then calculate. (2) Solve 5 problems using partial products and verify they match your standard algorithm answers. (3) Word problems: The Parthenon used 13,400 marble blocks. If each weighed about 22 tons, what was the total weight? A Greek theater seated 47 rows with 185 seats per row — total capacity? (4) Challenge: 347 x 256.

slides.text: Multiplication is a power tool for working with large numbers. Whether you use the standard algorithm or partial products, the key is understanding what you are doing, not just following steps. Estimation keeps you honest by catching errors before they become answers.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student accurately multiply multi-digit numbers, use partial products to verify, estimate products, and apply multiplication to word problems?

parent_notes: Multi-digit multiplication fluency is essential for all higher mathematics. The partial products method builds conceptual understanding, while the standard algorithm builds efficiency. Both matter. Practice at home with real calculations: estimating costs when shopping, calculating areas of rooms, or figuring out quantities for recipes. If your child struggles with the standard algorithm, partial products can bridge the gap.

title: Ancient Greek Democracy — The Birth of Government by the People
description: Students explore the revolutionary concept of democracy as it developed in ancient Athens. They examine the Assembly, the role of citizens, and the limitations of Athenian democracy, comparing it to modern democratic systems.
instructions:
1. Review the geography of Greece and how it shaped political development.
2. Define democracy: 'demos' (people) + 'kratos' (rule).
3. Explain the Athenian Assembly: who could participate and who was excluded.
4. Discuss the role of Pericles in strengthening Athenian democracy.
5. Examine daily life in democratic Athens: voting, jury duty, public debate.
6. Compare Athenian direct democracy with modern representative democracy.
7. Discuss who was EXCLUDED: women, enslaved people, non-citizens.
8. Analyze the tension between democratic ideals and actual practice.
9. Students create a Venn diagram comparing Athenian and modern democracy.
10. Debate: Was Athens truly democratic?

slides.heading: Ancient Greek Democracy
slides.subheading: The Birth of Government by the People

slides.setup_instructions: Print a map of ancient Athens showing the Agora and Pnyx hill. Prepare vocabulary cards for democracy terms. Select an age-appropriate excerpt from Pericles' Funeral Oration.

slides.text: Greece's geography — mountains and islands — created hundreds of small, independent city-states (poleis). Each developed its own government. Athens chose something revolutionary: rule by the people. The word 'democracy' comes from Greek: demos (people) + kratos (power or rule).

In the Athenian Assembly, every male citizen over 18 could speak and vote on laws, war, and taxes. This was DIRECT democracy — citizens voted on issues themselves, not through representatives. Meetings were held on the Pnyx hill, where 6,000 citizens could gather.

Pericles, Athens' greatest democratic leader, said: 'Our constitution is called a democracy because power is in the hands of the many, not the few.' Under Pericles, Athens flourished in art, philosophy, and architecture. The Parthenon was built during his leadership.

But Athenian democracy had enormous blind spots. Women could not vote or own property. Enslaved people (about 30% of the population) had no rights. Foreign residents could never become citizens. Only about 10-20% of the population could participate. Democracy for some, but not for all.

slides.prompt: Explore democracy: (1) Create a Venn diagram comparing Athenian and modern American democracy. Include at least 5 items in each section. (2) Read the Pericles excerpt. What does he believe makes Athens special? Do you agree? (3) Write a journal entry from the perspective of someone EXCLUDED from Athenian democracy: a woman, an enslaved person, or a foreign resident. What would you want to say to the Assembly? (4) Debate: Was Athens truly democratic if most people could not participate?

slides.text: Athens gave the world the idea that ordinary people could govern themselves — a revolutionary concept that still shapes our world. But their democracy was limited by who counted as 'the people.' The story of democracy since Athens has been the story of expanding that circle.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain the structure of Athenian democracy, identify who was included and excluded, compare ancient and modern democracy, and evaluate whether Athens was truly democratic?

parent_notes: The concept of democracy is both inspiring and complicated. Athens invented the idea of self-governance, but excluded the majority of its population. This tension — between democratic ideals and actual practice — is still relevant today. The journal activity asking students to write from an excluded perspective develops empathy and critical thinking about who gets to participate in society.

title: World Climate Zones — Understanding Earth's Climate Patterns
description: Students explore Earth's major climate zones and the factors that determine climate. They learn to distinguish between weather and climate, map the major zones, and understand how latitude, altitude, and ocean currents create different environments.
instructions:
1. Define climate vs. weather: climate is the long-term pattern, weather is daily conditions.
2. Introduce the three main climate zone groups: tropical, temperate, and polar.
3. Explain how latitude determines the amount of solar energy a region receives.
4. Discuss how altitude affects climate: higher is cooler.
5. Examine the role of ocean currents in moderating climate.
6. Map the major climate zones on a world map.
7. Compare daily life in different climate zones.
8. Discuss how climate shapes vegetation, agriculture, and human settlement.
9. Students color-code a world map with climate zones.
10. Research and present on the climate of ancient Greece.

slides.setup_instructions: Print blank world maps with latitude lines. Prepare climate zone description cards with temperature ranges and characteristics. Have a globe available to demonstrate latitude and solar angle.

slides.text: Weather is what happens today: sunny, rainy, 72 degrees. Climate is the PATTERN over decades: tropical, temperate, arid. You can have an unusually cold day in a hot climate. Climate tells us what to EXPECT; weather tells us what IS HAPPENING.

Latitude is the primary driver of climate. Near the equator (0 degrees), sunlight hits directly — creating tropical climates that are warm year-round. Near the poles (60-90 degrees), sunlight hits at an angle — creating cold polar climates. In between (30-60 degrees), temperate climates have distinct seasons.

Altitude adds another layer: for every 1,000 feet you climb, temperature drops about 3.5 degrees Fahrenheit. That is why mountains can have snow at the equator. Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania (3 degrees south of the equator) has glaciers at its summit, even though its base is tropical.

Ocean currents act as climate conveyor belts. The Gulf Stream carries warm water from the Caribbean to Europe, making London much warmer than cities at the same latitude in Canada. Cold currents along western coasts create dry conditions and fog. Water moderates temperature extremes.

slides.prompt: Map the climate zones: (1) Color-code a world map: red for tropical, green for temperate, blue for polar, yellow for arid, purple for Mediterranean. (2) Label the equator, Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn, and Arctic/Antarctic circles. (3) Identify which climate zone you live in and describe its characteristics. (4) Research ancient Greece's climate zone (Mediterranean) and explain how it influenced Greek agriculture, architecture, and daily life.

slides.text: Climate zones explain why different parts of the world look, feel, and function so differently. The same latitude, altitude, and ocean current forces that shaped ancient civilizations still shape human life today. Geography is destiny — at least partly.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student distinguish weather from climate, identify major climate zones and their characteristics, explain how latitude, altitude, and ocean currents affect climate, and connect climate to human settlement?

parent_notes: Climate zones provide a framework for understanding why different parts of the world are so different. The weather vs. climate distinction is important for understanding current events as well. Use a globe or map to explore together: Why is northern Europe warmer than northern Canada at the same latitude? Why are deserts common at 30 degrees latitude? These questions develop geographic thinking.

title: Island of the Blue Dolphins — Chapters 9-12: Survival and Self-Reliance
description: Students continue reading Island of the Blue Dolphins by Scott O'Dell, following Karana as she builds shelter, makes weapons, and learns to survive alone on the island. They analyze themes of resilience, self-reliance, and the relationship between humans and nature.
instructions:
1. Review events from previous chapters.
2. Read aloud chapters 9-12 with attention to descriptive language.
3. Discuss Karana's decision-making process for survival.
4. Analyze how she adapts traditional knowledge to new challenges.
5. Examine the theme of self-reliance: what does Karana learn about herself?
6. Discuss the conflict between cultural rules and survival needs.
7. Identify descriptive passages about the island's natural environment.
8. Students track Karana's survival skills in a character journal.
9. Compare Karana's challenges to other survival stories students know.
10. Journal response: What would you do in Karana's situation?
materials_needed: Island of the Blue Dolphins by Scott O'Dell

items: Island of the Blue Dolphins by Scott O'Dell
slides.setup_instructions: Have copies bookmarked at chapter 9. Prepare survival skills tracking charts listing categories: shelter, food, tools, clothing, defense. Have island map templates ready.

slides.text: Karana faces a profound dilemma: her tribe's tradition forbids women from making weapons. But she is alone, and wild dogs threaten her survival. She must choose between honoring tradition and ensuring her survival. This conflict — between cultural rules and personal necessity — is one of the novel's deepest themes.

Notice how O'Dell describes Karana's problem-solving process. She observes, experiments, fails, and tries again. Making a bow and arrows requires specific materials, precise construction, and practice. Survival is not just physical strength — it is intelligence, patience, and adaptability.

The island itself is almost a character. O'Dell describes the wind, waves, animals, and landscape with vivid sensory detail. These descriptions are not decoration — they show Karana's world and the forces she must work with and against.

Self-reliance means depending on yourself, but it also means understanding your environment. Karana learns to read the ocean, the seasons, and animal behavior. She builds a relationship with the natural world that is both practical and spiritual.

slides.prompt: Reading response: (1) Track Karana's survival skills: list every tool she makes, shelter she builds, and food source she discovers in chapters 9-12. (2) Draw a map of Karana's island based on the descriptions, showing her shelter, water sources, and important landmarks. (3) Journal: Karana breaks a cultural rule to survive. Write about a time when you had to go against expectations to do what you thought was right. How did it feel?

slides.text: Karana's survival story is about more than staying alive — it is about growing into a person who can think independently, solve problems creatively, and make difficult decisions. These qualities define resilience, which matters in every life, not just on a deserted island.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student analyze Karana's survival strategies, identify themes of self-reliance and cultural conflict, use textual evidence to support observations, and connect themes to personal experience?

parent_notes: Island of the Blue Dolphins is based on the true story of a Nicholeno woman who lived alone on San Nicolas Island for 18 years. The cultural conflict Karana faces is nuanced: traditions exist for reasons, but sometimes circumstances demand adaptation. This is an age-appropriate way to discuss when rules should be followed and when they might need to change. The survival skills tracking encourages close reading and attention to detail.

title: Vocabulary Building — Greek and Latin Roots for Complex Words
description: Students expand their vocabulary by studying Greek and Latin roots commonly found in academic English. They learn to decode unfamiliar words by analyzing root words, prefixes, and suffixes, building a foundation for advanced reading comprehension.
instructions:
1. Review previously learned root words and affixes.
2. Introduce new Greek roots: demos (people), kratos (power), logos (word/study), polis (city).
3. Introduce new Latin roots: multi (many), dict (say/speak), struct (build), port (carry).
4. Practice building words from roots: democracy, politics, structure, transport.
5. Model using root knowledge to decode unfamiliar words in context.
6. Play a root word matching game: roots to meanings to example words.
7. Students create a root word reference card with new roots.
8. Apply root word knowledge to decode words in a history text about Greece.
9. Generate lists of words sharing common roots.
10. Write sentences using newly decoded vocabulary.

slides.heading: Greek and Latin Roots
slides.subheading: Unlocking the Code of Complex Words

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare root cards with the root, meaning, and example words. Print a reference chart of all roots studied so far. Select a history text excerpt containing words with Greek and Latin roots.

slides.text: Greek and Latin roots are the building blocks of English academic vocabulary. Over 60% of English words have Greek or Latin origins. Knowing roots is like having a decoder ring: you can figure out the meaning of words you have never seen before.

Greek roots from democracy and government: DEMOS = people (democracy, demographics, epidemic). KRATOS = power/rule (democracy, aristocracy, bureaucracy). POLIS = city (politics, police, metropolitan). LOGOS = word/study (biology, geology, technology).

Latin roots for everyday academic words: MULTI = many (multiply, multimedia, multicultural). DICT = say/speak (dictionary, predict, contradict). STRUCT = build (structure, construct, instruct). PORT = carry (transport, import, export, portable).

Decoding in action: You encounter 'metropolitan.' You know METRO relates to measure/mother city and POLIS means city. So metropolitan means 'relating to a large city.' You see 'infrastructure.' INFRA = below, STRUCT = build. Infrastructure is the underlying structure — roads, pipes, wires — that a society is built on.

slides.prompt: Root word practice: (1) Create root word cards: For each of the 8 new roots, write the root, meaning, and 3 example words on an index card. (2) Word detective: Find 10 words with Greek or Latin roots in the history text excerpt. Write each word, identify the root, and explain how the root connects to the word's meaning. (3) Word builder: How many words can you create from these roots? Combine prefixes, roots, and suffixes. (4) Write 5 sentences about ancient Greece using words with the roots you learned today.

slides.text: Every time you learn a root, you unlock dozens of words. Greek and Latin roots are particularly powerful in science, history, and medicine — fields where precise vocabulary matters. You are building a decoder that will serve you through high school, college, and beyond.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student define new Greek and Latin roots, identify roots in unfamiliar words, use root knowledge to determine word meanings, and apply new vocabulary in context?

parent_notes: Root word study is one of the most efficient vocabulary-building strategies. Each root unlocks many words. The Greek roots this week connect directly to the democracy history lesson, reinforcing learning across subjects. Practice at home: when your child encounters an unfamiliar word, ask them to look for roots they recognize before reaching for a dictionary.

title: Division Review — Long Division with Multi-Digit Dividends
description: Students strengthen their long division skills with multi-digit dividends and one- and two-digit divisors. They practice estimation, check answers with multiplication, and apply division to real-world problems.
instructions:
1. Review division as the inverse of multiplication.
2. Model long division with a one-digit divisor step by step.
3. Introduce estimation for the first digit of the quotient.
4. Practice division with remainders: interpret remainders in context.
5. Introduce division with two-digit divisors.
6. Model checking division answers using multiplication.
7. Solve word problems requiring division: sharing equally, grouping.
8. Apply to ancient Greek contexts: dividing soldiers into units, distributing supplies.
9. Students practice a set of long division problems.
10. Challenge: division problems requiring interpretation of remainders.

slides.setup_instructions: Print long division worksheets at three difficulty levels. Have graph paper available to help students keep digits aligned. Create the step-by-step guide showing Divide-Multiply-Subtract-Bring Down.

slides.text: Long division follows four steps that repeat: Divide, Multiply, Subtract, Bring down (DMSB). For 756 divided by 4: How many 4s in 7? One, remainder 3. How many 4s in 35? Eight, remainder 3. How many 4s in 36? Nine. Answer: 189.

Estimation helps with two-digit divisors. For 1,847 divided by 23: estimate 23 as about 20. How many 20s in 184? About 9. Try 9: 23 x 9 = 207 (too big). Try 8: 23 x 8 = 184 (perfect). Estimation narrows your choices.

Remainders require interpretation. 25 students need rides. Each car holds 4. 25 divided by 4 = 6 remainder 1. You need 7 cars (round up). But if dividing 25 cookies among 4 friends: each gets 6, with 1 left over (remainder stays). Context determines how to handle the remainder.

Always check: multiply your quotient by the divisor and add the remainder. The result should equal the dividend. For 756 / 4 = 189: check 189 x 4 = 756. This verification habit catches errors and builds confidence.

slides.prompt: Division practice: (1) Solve 8 long division problems with one-digit divisors. Check each with multiplication. (2) Solve 4 problems with two-digit divisors. (3) Remainder problems: 347 students attend a field trip. Each bus holds 45. How many buses? A farmer has 2,500 apples to pack in crates of 36. How many full crates? How many apples left? (4) Create a division word problem set in ancient Greece and solve it.

slides.text: Division is multiplication's partner — they undo each other. The DMSB algorithm works for any division problem, and checking with multiplication ensures accuracy. These skills will support fraction work, ratios, and algebra.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student perform long division with multi-digit dividends, work with two-digit divisors, interpret remainders in context, and verify answers?

parent_notes: Long division is often considered the most challenging elementary arithmetic operation. The key is practice with understanding, not just memorization of steps. Graph paper helps keep digits aligned. The verification step (multiplying to check) builds mathematical habits of mind. If your child struggles with two-digit divisors, practice estimation skills: rounding the divisor to the nearest ten makes the first step easier.

title: Plate Tectonics — Earth's Moving Puzzle Pieces
description: Students discover that Earth's surface is made of massive plates that move, collide, and pull apart. They learn about continental drift, the evidence that supports plate tectonics, and how plate movement shapes Earth's geography over millions of years.
instructions:
1. Review Earth's layers from previous science lessons.
2. Introduce plate tectonics: Earth's crust is broken into large plates.
3. Present the evidence: continental puzzle fit, matching fossils, similar rock layers.
4. Explain Alfred Wegener's continental drift hypothesis.
5. Discuss seafloor spreading and how it proved plate movement.
6. Identify the major tectonic plates on a world map.
7. Demonstrate plate movement using a hands-on model.
8. Discuss the three types of plate boundaries: convergent, divergent, transform.
9. Students map tectonic plates and label boundary types.
10. Connect plate tectonics to earthquakes and volcanoes.

slides.setup_instructions: Print Pangaea puzzle cutouts showing how continents fit together. Prepare a hard-boiled egg to crack gently, demonstrating how Earth's crust is like a cracked shell. Print tectonic plate maps.

slides.text: Look at a world map: South America and Africa look like puzzle pieces that fit together. This is not a coincidence. About 250 million years ago, all continents were joined in one supercontinent called Pangaea. They have been slowly drifting apart ever since.

The evidence is compelling: Identical fossils of Mesosaurus (a freshwater reptile) are found in both South America and Africa — it could not have swum across an ocean. Similar rock layers and mountain chains match across oceans. Tropical plant fossils are found in Antarctica. The continents WERE connected.

Earth's crust is like the cracked shell of a hard-boiled egg. The cracks divide the crust into about 15 major plates. These plates float on the semi-liquid mantle below, moving 1-10 centimeters per year — about as fast as your fingernails grow. Slow, but over millions of years, continents cross oceans.

Three types of boundaries: CONVERGENT — plates push together (creating mountains or subduction zones). DIVERGENT — plates pull apart (creating rift valleys and new ocean floor). TRANSFORM — plates slide past each other (creating earthquake zones like the San Andreas Fault).

slides.prompt: Explore plate tectonics: (1) Assemble the Pangaea puzzle: fit the continents together as they were 250 million years ago. Identify matching coastlines. (2) Map the major tectonic plates on a blank world map. Color each plate a different color and label it. (3) Mark plate boundaries: use red for convergent, blue for divergent, and green for transform. (4) In your journal, explain in your own words: What is the evidence that continents were once connected?

slides.text: Plate tectonics explains why continents look like puzzle pieces, why mountains exist, and why earthquakes and volcanoes occur in specific locations. The ground beneath your feet is moving right now — you just cannot feel it because it moves so slowly.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain plate tectonics theory, cite evidence for continental drift, identify major plates and boundary types, and connect plate movement to geographic features?

parent_notes: Plate tectonics is one of science's great unifying theories. The Pangaea puzzle activity is surprisingly powerful — when children physically fit the continents together, the theory becomes real. The hard-boiled egg model effectively demonstrates a cracked crust floating on a semi-liquid interior. Look for earthquake and volcano news to connect this lesson to current events. The fact that plates move at fingernail speed helps children grasp geological time scales.

title: Greek Sculpture — The Art of the Human Form
description: Students explore ancient Greek sculpture and its revolutionary approach to depicting the human body. They examine the progression from Archaic to Classical styles, analyze proportion and movement, and create a figure drawing inspired by Greek ideals.
instructions:
1. Connect to Greek democracy: art reflected Athens' values of beauty and excellence.
2. Introduce Greek sculpture periods: Archaic (stiff, frontal) to Classical (natural, dynamic).
3. Analyze the Archaic kouros: formal, symmetrical, one foot forward.
4. Compare with Classical sculpture: contrapposto, natural movement, emotion.
5. Discuss Greek ideals of proportion: the body as mathematical harmony.
6. Examine famous works: Discobolus, Venus de Milo, and the Parthenon frieze.
7. Introduce contrapposto: weight shift creating natural stance.
8. Practice drawing the human figure with correct proportions.
9. Students create a figure drawing using Greek proportion guidelines.
10. Share and discuss how proportion creates the illusion of life.

slides.heading: Greek Sculpture
slides.subheading: The Art of the Human Form

slides.setup_instructions: Print photographs of Archaic kouros figures alongside Classical sculptures like Discobolus and Venus de Milo. Prepare a figure proportion guide showing the 7-8 head-height system.

slides.text: Greek sculptors revolutionized art by making stone look alive. Early Archaic sculptures were stiff and formal — both feet flat, arms at sides, a fixed smile. Over 200 years, Greek artists learned to capture movement, emotion, and the natural beauty of the human body.

The key breakthrough was contrapposto: shifting weight to one leg so the hips and shoulders tilt in opposite directions. This simple change made figures look like they were about to move. Compare an Egyptian statue (perfectly symmetrical) with a Greek Classical figure (weight shifted, one hip higher) — the difference is dramatic.

Greek artists used mathematical proportions: the body is about 7-8 head-lengths tall. The navel divides the body at the golden ratio. Arms span equals height. These proportions create the sense of harmony and balance that Greeks valued in all things.

The Discobolus (Discus Thrower) captures a split second of athletic motion frozen in marble. The figure is coiled with energy, about to release the discus. Greek sculptors did not just show what the body LOOKS like; they showed what it DOES — the tension, energy, and power of human movement.

slides.prompt: Create a figure drawing: (1) Study the proportion guide: mark 8 equal sections on your paper for head-lengths. (2) Sketch a standing figure using the proportion guidelines. Place the head, shoulders, hips, knees, and feet at the correct heights. (3) Add contrapposto: shift weight to one leg, tilt the hips and shoulders. (4) Refine your drawing, adding details like arms, hands, and facial features. (5) Optional challenge: draw your figure in an action pose inspired by Greek athletics.

slides.text: Greek sculptors proved that art and mathematics are partners. Proportion creates beauty, contrapposto creates life, and careful observation creates truth. These principles still guide artists today, over 2,500 years later.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify the differences between Archaic and Classical Greek sculpture, explain contrapposto and proportion, and create a figure drawing using Greek proportion guidelines?

parent_notes: Greek sculpture connects art, mathematics, and culture in a powerful way. The proportion system (body = 7-8 heads tall) gives students a practical framework for figure drawing. Do not worry about artistic perfection — the goal is understanding proportion and the revolution of showing natural movement. Visit a museum's Greek collection if possible, or explore online museum collections together.

title: Time Management — Planning and Prioritizing Tasks
description: Students develop essential time management skills by learning to plan their week, prioritize tasks, distinguish between urgent and important activities, and create personal schedules. They apply these skills to managing academic work and personal responsibilities.
instructions:
1. Discuss why time management matters: everyone has the same 24 hours.
2. Introduce the concept of priorities: not all tasks are equally important.
3. Teach the Eisenhower Matrix: urgent/important, important/not urgent, urgent/not important, neither.
4. Practice categorizing common tasks using the matrix.
5. Model creating a weekly schedule with time blocks.
6. Discuss the importance of including breaks, exercise, and free time.
7. Introduce task estimation: how long does each task actually take?
8. Practice breaking large projects into smaller, manageable steps.
9. Students create a personalized weekly schedule.
10. Reflect on current time use and identify one area for improvement.

slides.setup_instructions: Print Eisenhower Matrix templates and blank weekly schedule grids. Prepare task cards listing common student activities (homework, sports, chores, reading, screen time, etc.) for sorting practice.

slides.text: Everyone gets exactly 24 hours per day — no more, no less. The difference between feeling rushed and feeling in control is not having more time; it is managing time wisely. Time management is a skill, and like any skill, it improves with practice.

The Eisenhower Matrix sorts tasks into four boxes: (1) URGENT and IMPORTANT: Do immediately (homework due tomorrow). (2) IMPORTANT but not urgent: Schedule time (studying for next week's test). (3) URGENT but not important: Delegate or do quickly (answering a non-critical message). (4) Neither: Eliminate or minimize (mindless scrolling).

Most people spend too much time in Box 3 (urgent but not important) and Box 4 (neither). Successful people spend most time in Box 2 (important but not urgent) — planning, studying, exercising, building skills. Box 2 prevents Box 1 emergencies.

Breaking big projects into small steps makes them manageable. 'Write a research paper' is overwhelming. But 'choose a topic' (15 min), 'find 3 sources' (30 min), 'write an outline' (20 min), 'draft introduction' (25 min) — each step is achievable. This is how every big goal gets accomplished.

slides.prompt: Build your time management system: (1) Sort 15 task cards into the Eisenhower Matrix. Discuss your choices with a partner. (2) Track your time for a typical day: estimate how many hours you spend on school, homework, meals, exercise, screen time, sleep, and free time. Does it add up to 24? (3) Create a weekly schedule: block out fixed commitments first (school, meals, sleep), then schedule important activities, then add free time. Use colors for different categories. (4) Identify one time management improvement you will try this week.

slides.text: Time management is not about filling every minute with productivity — it is about making intentional choices. When you plan your time, you control your life instead of reacting to whatever demands your attention. Free time is important too, but it should be chosen, not accidental.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student categorize tasks using the Eisenhower Matrix, create a balanced weekly schedule, break large projects into manageable steps, and identify areas for time management improvement?

parent_notes: Time management is one of the most valuable life skills and one that many adults still struggle with. The Eisenhower Matrix provides a practical framework for making daily decisions about where to spend time. Help your child implement their weekly schedule, but expect adjustments — the first attempt is always imperfect. The most important insight is that Box 2 activities (important but not urgent) prevent emergencies.

title: Complex Sentences — Relative Clauses with Who, Which, and That
description: Students expand their complex sentence skills by learning to use relative clauses. They practice embedding additional information into sentences using relative pronouns (who, which, that), creating more detailed and sophisticated writing.
instructions:
1. Review subordinating conjunctions from Day 1.
2. Introduce relative clauses: clauses that describe a noun in the sentence.
3. Define relative pronouns: who (people), which (things, non-essential), that (things, essential).
4. Model embedding relative clauses into simple sentences.
5. Distinguish essential (restrictive) from non-essential (non-restrictive) clauses.
6. Teach comma rules: non-essential clauses use commas, essential clauses do not.
7. Practice combining sentences using relative pronouns.
8. Students identify relative clauses in published text.
9. Write a paragraph about Greek philosophers using relative clauses.
10. Peer edit for correct relative pronoun use and punctuation.

slides.heading: Relative Clauses
slides.subheading: Adding Detail with Who, Which, and That

slides.setup_instructions: Create a relative pronoun reference chart showing who/which/that usage. Prepare sentence combining worksheets. Select published text excerpts with clear relative clause examples.

slides.text: A relative clause gives more information about a noun. Instead of two sentences: 'Socrates was a philosopher. He questioned everything.' One complex sentence: 'Socrates, who questioned everything, was a philosopher.' The relative clause 'who questioned everything' is embedded inside the sentence.

Choose the right relative pronoun: WHO for people ('The teacher who inspired me'). WHICH for things, with commas ('The Parthenon, which took 15 years to build'). THAT for things, no commas ('The temple that stood on the Acropolis'). Who and which add extra information; that identifies which one.

Essential vs. non-essential: 'The philosopher who drank hemlock was Socrates' — essential (tells us WHICH philosopher, no commas). 'Socrates, who drank hemlock, was Athens' most famous philosopher' — non-essential (adds extra information, uses commas). Remove a non-essential clause and the sentence still makes sense.

Relative clauses add sophistication to your writing. Compare: 'Plato started a school. The school was called the Academy.' With: 'Plato started a school that he called the Academy.' Or even better: 'Plato, who was Socrates' most famous student, started a school called the Academy.' Each version adds more information in fewer words.

slides.prompt: Practice relative clauses: (1) Combine 8 sentence pairs using who, which, or that. (2) Add commas where needed for non-essential clauses. (3) Find 5 relative clauses in the published text excerpt. Identify the relative pronoun and whether the clause is essential or non-essential. (4) Write a paragraph about Greek philosophers (Socrates, Plato, Aristotle) using at least 4 relative clauses with varied pronouns.

slides.text: Relative clauses let you pack more information into your sentences without making them feel choppy. They are the tool that transforms 'See Spot run' writing into mature, detailed prose. Master who, which, and that, and your writing gains both clarity and elegance.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student use relative pronouns correctly, distinguish essential from non-essential clauses, apply comma rules, and write complex sentences with embedded relative clauses?

parent_notes: Relative clauses represent a significant step in writing maturity. The who/which/that distinction and comma rules may take time to master. The key insight is that essential clauses narrow down which one you mean (no commas), while non-essential clauses add bonus information (commas). When reading together, point out relative clauses in books and articles — they are everywhere once you know to look for them.

title: Factors and Multiples — Building Number Relationships
description: Students explore the relationships between numbers through factors and multiples. They learn to find all factors of a number, identify common factors and multiples, and begin to understand how these concepts connect to fractions and division.
instructions:
1. Define factors: numbers that divide evenly into another number.
2. Practice finding all factors of numbers using systematic pairing.
3. Define multiples: the products of a number with counting numbers.
4. Practice listing multiples and identifying patterns.
5. Introduce common factors and greatest common factor (GCF).
6. Introduce common multiples and least common multiple (LCM).
7. Apply factors to real-world problems: arranging items in equal rows.
8. Connect factors and multiples to division and multiplication.
9. Students complete a factors and multiples investigation.
10. Challenge: find GCF and LCM for number pairs.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare factor pair charts. Have multiplication tables and colored counters available. Print Venn diagram templates for finding GCF and LCM.

slides.text: Factors are numbers that divide evenly into another number. Factors of 12: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 12. Find them systematically in pairs: 1x12, 2x6, 3x4. When your pairs start repeating, you have found them all. Every number has at least two factors: 1 and itself.

Multiples are the opposite: the products you get when multiplying a number by 1, 2, 3, 4... Multiples of 7: 7, 14, 21, 28, 35, 42... Multiples go on forever. Every number has infinitely many multiples. Multiples are what you recite when skip counting.

The Greatest Common Factor (GCF) is the largest factor shared by two numbers. Factors of 12: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 12. Factors of 18: 1, 2, 3, 6, 9, 18. Common factors: 1, 2, 3, 6. GCF = 6. This is essential for simplifying fractions: 12/18 simplifies to 2/3 by dividing both by the GCF of 6.

The Least Common Multiple (LCM) is the smallest multiple shared by two numbers. Multiples of 4: 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24... Multiples of 6: 6, 12, 18, 24... Common multiples: 12, 24... LCM = 12. This is essential for adding fractions with different denominators.

slides.prompt: Factor and multiple investigation: (1) Find ALL factors of: 24, 36, 48, and 60. Use systematic pairing. (2) List the first 10 multiples of 6, 8, and 12. Circle common multiples. (3) Find the GCF of: (12, 20), (18, 27), (24, 36). (4) Find the LCM of: (4, 6), (8, 12), (6, 9). (5) Real-world: You have 24 red tiles and 36 blue tiles. What is the largest square pattern you can make using all tiles equally?

slides.text: Factors and multiples reveal the hidden relationships between numbers. GCF simplifies fractions; LCM finds common denominators. These tools will be essential as you work with fractions, ratios, and algebraic expressions.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student find all factors of a number, list multiples, determine GCF and LCM, and apply these concepts to problems?

parent_notes: Factors and multiples are foundational for fraction work. The GCF is used to simplify fractions; the LCM is used to find common denominators. The systematic pairing method for finding factors builds organizational thinking. Practice at home with everyday numbers: 'What are all the ways to arrange 24 chairs in equal rows?' Understanding these relationships makes fraction operations much easier.

title: Sparta vs. Athens — Two Visions of Greek Society
description: Students compare the two most powerful Greek city-states: Athens, focused on democracy, art, and philosophy, and Sparta, focused on military discipline, strength, and collective sacrifice. They analyze how geography and values shaped radically different societies.
instructions:
1. Review Athenian democracy from Day 1.
2. Introduce Sparta: a military society fundamentally different from Athens.
3. Describe the agoge: Spartan military training beginning at age 7.
4. Compare education: Athens valued philosophy and art; Sparta valued combat and endurance.
5. Compare women's roles: Spartan women had more freedom than Athenian women.
6. Discuss government: Sparta's dual kings and council vs. Athens' Assembly.
7. Examine the strengths and weaknesses of each system.
8. Students create a comparison chart of Athens and Sparta.
9. Role-play: argue for your assigned city-state's superiority.
10. Journal: Which city-state would you prefer to live in? Why?
materials_needed: Athens vs. Sparta comparison chart template

items: Athens vs. Sparta comparison chart template
slides.setup_instructions: Print comparison chart templates with categories: government, education, women, military, values, arts. Prepare role-play cards assigning students to argue for Athens or Sparta.

slides.text: Athens and Sparta were both Greek, but they could not have been more different. Athens valued democracy, education, art, and debate. Sparta valued military strength, obedience, discipline, and sacrifice. They were rivals for centuries, representing two fundamentally different answers to the question: What makes a great society?

In Sparta, boys left home at age 7 for the agoge — brutal military training. They learned to endure cold, hunger, and pain. They slept on hard ground. Education meant fighting, not reading. At age 20, they became soldiers. At 30, they could participate in government. The individual existed to serve the state.

Surprisingly, Spartan women had more rights than Athenian women. They exercised, owned property, and spoke publicly. Spartans believed strong mothers produced strong warriors. In Athens, women were confined to the home and had no political rights. Neither society achieved equality, but they differed greatly.

The great test came with the Persian Wars: Athens and Sparta united against Persia. Sparta's 300 warriors held Thermopylae; Athens' navy won at Salamis. Together they saved Greece. But after the external threat passed, they turned on each other in the Peloponnesian War (431-404 BC). Sparta won the war but lost its purpose.

slides.prompt: Compare and debate: (1) Complete the Athens vs. Sparta comparison chart covering government, education, women's rights, military, arts, and values. (2) Role-play debate: You will be assigned Athens or Sparta. Prepare 3 arguments for why YOUR city-state is the better model for society. (3) After the debate, journal honestly: Which city-state would you rather live in? Consider your gender, social class, and values in your answer.

slides.text: Athens and Sparta represent two answers to a timeless question: Should a society prioritize individual freedom or collective strength? Neither was perfect. Athens had democracy but excluded most people. Sparta had equality among warriors but crushed individual expression. The tension between these values continues today.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student compare Athens and Sparta across multiple categories, evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of each society, and articulate a supported personal preference?

parent_notes: The Athens vs. Sparta comparison is one of history's most engaging debates. It connects to modern discussions about individual freedom vs. collective responsibility, and about what values a society should prioritize. The role-play debate builds argumentation skills. The journal prompt about which city-state to live in often reveals interesting values-based reasoning.

title: Climate Zones in Detail — Tropical and Arid Regions
description: Students take a deeper look at tropical and arid climate zones, examining the specific conditions, vegetation, wildlife, and human adaptations in these regions. They compare life near the equator with life in the world's great deserts.
instructions:
1. Review climate zones from Day 1.
2. Examine tropical climates: wet tropical, tropical monsoon, tropical savanna.
3. Discuss tropical rainforest characteristics: heat, humidity, biodiversity.
4. Examine arid climates: hot desert and cold desert.
5. Discuss desert characteristics: extreme temperatures, limited water.
6. Compare human adaptations in tropical vs. arid zones.
7. Examine how climate influences architecture, clothing, and daily routines.
8. Students research a specific tropical and arid location.
9. Create climate zone comparison posters.
10. Discuss how climate change may alter these zones.

slides.setup_instructions: Print photographs of tropical rainforests and deserts. Prepare climate data charts showing monthly temperature and rainfall for representative locations. Have poster paper available.

slides.text: Tropical climates are found between the Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn (23.5 degrees N and S). They are warm year-round (average above 64 degrees F every month) and receive abundant rainfall. Tropical rainforests hold more than half of all species on Earth in just 6% of the land area.

Arid climates receive less than 10 inches of rain per year. Hot deserts like the Sahara can reach 130 degrees F during the day and drop below freezing at night. Cold deserts like the Gobi in Mongolia have harsh winters. About one-third of Earth's land surface is arid or semi-arid.

Humans adapt to climate: In tropical regions, buildings have large windows for ventilation, roofs are steep to shed rain, and clothing is light. In deserts, buildings have thick walls for insulation, small windows to block heat, and clothing covers the body to protect from sun and sand.

Both zones face challenges. Tropical regions: deforestation, soil depletion, disease. Arid regions: water scarcity, desertification, limited agriculture. Climate change threatens both: tropical forests absorb carbon but are being cut down; deserts are expanding into previously productive land.

slides.prompt: Climate zone study: (1) Research one tropical location (Amazon, Congo, Southeast Asia) and one arid location (Sahara, Atacama, Gobi). For each, find: average temperature, rainfall, vegetation, wildlife, and how people live there. (2) Create a comparison poster with two halves: tropical on one side, arid on the other. Include drawings, data, and key facts. (3) Write a paragraph explaining how climate shapes daily life in each zone.

slides.text: Tropical and arid zones represent Earth's extremes of moisture. Both are fascinating, both support unique life forms, and both face threats from human activity. Understanding climate zones helps us appreciate the diversity of our planet and the ingenuity of human adaptation.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe characteristics of tropical and arid zones, explain human adaptations to each climate, compare the two zones, and identify challenges each faces?

parent_notes: The tropical vs. arid comparison makes climate zones concrete and visual. The poster activity allows creative expression alongside geographic learning. If possible, explore photographs or videos of daily life in a tropical rainforest village and a desert community — the contrast is striking. Connect to your family's climate zone: how does your local climate shape your home, clothing, and activities?

title: Island of the Blue Dolphins — Chapters 13-16: Companionship and Courage
description: Students continue reading as Karana forms an unexpected bond with the wild dog leader she once feared. They explore themes of loneliness, the human need for connection, and how compassion can transform relationships.
instructions:
1. Review Karana's survival progress from previous chapters.
2. Read aloud chapters 13-16.
3. Discuss Karana's decision to befriend the wild dog Rontu.
4. Analyze the transformation of their relationship from enemies to companions.
5. Examine the theme of loneliness and the need for companionship.
6. Discuss how Karana's character changes through her relationship with Rontu.
7. Identify how O'Dell uses sensory details to describe the island setting.
8. Students track character development in their journals.
9. Compare Karana's experience of isolation to other stories of solitude.
10. Creative writing: Write a scene from Rontu's perspective.
materials_needed: Island of the Blue Dolphins by Scott O'Dell

items: Island of the Blue Dolphins by Scott O'Dell
slides.setup_instructions: Bookmark at chapter 13. Prepare character development trackers with space for noting changes in Karana's emotions, decisions, and relationships.

slides.text: Karana's decision to befriend the very animal that killed her brother is remarkable. Instead of revenge, she chooses compassion. Nursing the wounded dog back to health transforms both of them: Karana gains a companion, and the wild dog becomes loyal. This choice defines Karana's character.

O'Dell shows loneliness not through Karana saying 'I am lonely' but through her actions: talking to animals, naming the wind, finding joy in small pleasures. When Rontu arrives, the change is immediate — she has someone to talk to, work alongside, and share her world with. Companionship transforms survival into living.

Pay attention to O'Dell's sensory descriptions: the sound of waves, the smell of cooking fish, the feel of wind. These details put you on the island alongside Karana. Great writers do not tell you a place is beautiful — they make you see, hear, smell, and feel it yourself.

Karana's growth is internal as well as external. She has gone from a girl who needed her community to a young woman who provides for herself. But her befriending of Rontu shows that strength and compassion can coexist. Being tough enough to survive alone AND gentle enough to heal an enemy — that is true courage.

slides.prompt: Reading response: (1) Track Karana's character development: Create a before-and-after chart showing how she has changed since the beginning. Include emotions, skills, relationships, and outlook. (2) Find 3 passages with vivid sensory details. For each, identify which senses O'Dell engages and why the detail matters. (3) Creative writing: Write a scene from chapters 13-16 from Rontu's perspective. What does the dog think and feel as Karana nurses him back to health?

slides.text: Karana teaches us that the bravest choice is not always fighting — sometimes it is extending compassion to an enemy. Her bond with Rontu shows that connection is a basic human need, and that kindness can transform the most unlikely relationships.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student analyze Karana's character development, identify themes of loneliness and companionship, cite specific textual evidence, and write creatively from an alternate perspective?

parent_notes: The Karana-Rontu relationship is the emotional heart of the novel. Choosing compassion over revenge is a powerful theme for this age group. The creative writing prompt (writing from Rontu's perspective) develops empathy and perspective-taking skills. Discuss with your child: Has there been a time when choosing kindness over anger changed a situation?

title: Writing Workshop — Crafting Complex Sentences in Paragraphs
description: Students apply their complex sentence skills to paragraph writing. They practice combining short, choppy sentences into flowing paragraphs using subordinating conjunctions and relative clauses, improving the rhythm and sophistication of their writing.
instructions:
1. Review complex sentence types from Days 1 and 3.
2. Read a paragraph of only simple sentences — notice the choppy rhythm.
3. Model revising the paragraph using complex sentences.
4. Discuss sentence variety: mixing simple, compound, and complex sentences.
5. Practice identifying choppy writing in sample paragraphs.
6. Model the revision process: find sentences to combine.
7. Discuss rhythm in writing: vary sentence length for effect.
8. Students revise a provided choppy paragraph into flowing prose.
9. Apply skills to their own writing: revise a previous draft.
10. Peer review focusing on sentence variety and complexity.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare before-and-after paragraph examples. Create a sentence variety checklist. Have student writing portfolios available for revision practice.

slides.text: Listen to this: 'Athens was a city. It was in Greece. It had democracy. Citizens could vote. Women could not vote.' Every sentence is simple and short. The rhythm is choppy and boring. Now: 'Athens, which was a powerful city in Greece, developed the world's first democracy, although only male citizens could vote.' Same information, but flowing and connected.

Good writing mixes sentence types. A short simple sentence can be powerful: 'Socrates refused to flee.' But if every sentence is short, the writing feels childish. Complex sentences connect ideas: 'Although his friends begged him to escape, Socrates refused to flee because he believed in obeying the law.'

Rhythm in writing comes from varying sentence LENGTH. A long complex sentence followed by a short simple sentence creates emphasis. 'Although Athens valued individual freedom, artistic expression, and philosophical inquiry above all other virtues, the city excluded most of its population from democratic participation. The irony was profound.'

When revising, look for sentences that share a subject or have a cause-effect relationship. These are natural candidates for combining. But do not make every sentence complex — that creates a different kind of monotony. Aim for variety: some simple, some compound, some complex.

slides.prompt: Revision practice: (1) Revise the provided choppy paragraph about ancient Greece. Combine at least 4 pairs of sentences using subordinating conjunctions or relative pronouns. Keep at least 2 short sentences for emphasis. (2) Select a piece from your writing portfolio. Identify 3 places where sentences could be combined into complex sentences. Revise those sections. (3) Read both versions aloud. Which sounds better? Which flows more naturally? (4) Peer review: Exchange revised paragraphs and evaluate sentence variety.

slides.text: The difference between adequate writing and excellent writing often comes down to sentence variety. When you can mix simple, compound, and complex sentences with intention — choosing each type for its effect — your writing comes alive with rhythm and sophistication.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify choppy writing, revise paragraphs using complex sentences, maintain sentence variety, and evaluate the rhythm and flow of writing?

parent_notes: This lesson connects grammar knowledge to real writing improvement. The before-and-after paragraph comparison makes the value of complex sentences immediately visible. When your child writes at home, encourage them to read their work aloud. If it sounds choppy, ask: 'Can any of these sentences be combined?' The rhythm of good writing becomes natural with practice.

title: Prime and Composite Numbers — The Building Blocks of Mathematics
description: Students discover prime and composite numbers, learning that every number can be broken down into prime factors. They use the Sieve of Eratosthenes to find primes and practice prime factorization using factor trees.
instructions:
1. Review factors from Day 3.
2. Define prime numbers: exactly two factors (1 and itself). Define composite: more than two factors.
3. Use the Sieve of Eratosthenes to find all primes to 100.
4. Discuss patterns in prime numbers: why are most primes odd?
5. Introduce prime factorization: breaking a number into its prime building blocks.
6. Model factor trees as a visual tool for prime factorization.
7. Practice prime factorization of various numbers.
8. Show that prime factorization is unique for every number.
9. Students complete a prime number investigation.
10. Connect prime factorization to finding GCF and LCM.
materials_needed: Hundreds chart for Sieve of Eratosthenes

items: Hundreds chart for Sieve of Eratosthenes
slides.setup_instructions: Print hundreds charts (1-100) for the sieve activity. Prepare factor tree templates. Have colored pencils ready for crossing off composite numbers on the chart.

slides.text: A prime number has exactly TWO factors: 1 and itself. Examples: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13. A composite number has MORE than two factors. Examples: 4, 6, 8, 9, 10, 12. The number 1 is special: it is neither prime nor composite (it has only ONE factor). 2 is the only even prime.

The Sieve of Eratosthenes (invented by a Greek mathematician!) finds all primes. Start with 2: circle it, cross out all multiples of 2. Move to 3: circle it, cross out multiples of 3. Move to 5 (4 is already crossed out): circle it, cross out multiples. Continue. The numbers left uncrossed are prime.

Prime factorization breaks any composite number into its prime building blocks using a factor tree. For 60: split into 6 x 10. Split 6 into 2 x 3. Split 10 into 2 x 5. So 60 = 2 x 2 x 3 x 5. No matter how you split 60, you always get the same prime factors. This is the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic.

Prime factorization helps find GCF and LCM. For GCF of 24 (2x2x2x3) and 36 (2x2x3x3): shared primes are 2x2x3 = 12. For LCM: take the highest power of each prime: 2x2x2x3x3 = 72. This method always works, even for large numbers.

slides.prompt: Prime number investigation: (1) Complete the Sieve of Eratosthenes for 1-100. How many primes are there? List them. (2) Create factor trees for: 48, 72, 100, and 180. Write the prime factorization. (3) Use prime factorization to find GCF and LCM of (48, 72) and (60, 100). (4) Twin primes are primes that differ by 2 (like 11 and 13). Find all twin prime pairs under 100.

slides.text: Prime numbers are the atoms of mathematics — every number is built from them. The ancient Greeks discovered this fact, and it remains one of the most beautiful ideas in mathematics. Mathematicians still search for patterns in prime numbers today.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify prime and composite numbers, use the Sieve of Eratosthenes, create factor trees, and apply prime factorization to find GCF and LCM?

parent_notes: The Sieve of Eratosthenes is a satisfying hands-on activity that makes prime numbers tangible. Factor trees are a visual tool that many students find engaging. Prime numbers fascinate mathematicians to this day — the largest known prime has millions of digits. If your child enjoys this topic, explore the twin primes conjecture or the concept that primes become rarer as numbers get larger but never disappear entirely.

title: Plate Boundaries — Volcanoes, Earthquakes, and Mountain Building
description: Students explore what happens at tectonic plate boundaries, connecting plate movement to volcanoes, earthquakes, and mountain formation. They map the Ring of Fire and investigate why natural disasters occur in predictable locations.
instructions:
1. Review plate tectonics and boundary types from Day 2.
2. Examine convergent boundaries in detail: what happens when plates collide?
3. Explain subduction: one plate diving under another, creating volcanoes.
4. Examine divergent boundaries: new crust forming at mid-ocean ridges.
5. Examine transform boundaries: plates grinding past each other, causing earthquakes.
6. Map the Ring of Fire: the circle of volcanoes and earthquakes around the Pacific.
7. Discuss how earthquakes are measured (Richter scale) and how they cause damage.
8. Students map earthquake and volcano locations and compare to plate boundaries.
9. Investigate why certain regions are earthquake-prone.
10. Discuss earthquake preparedness and safety.

slides.setup_instructions: Print detailed diagrams of each boundary type. Prepare a Ring of Fire map. Compile earthquake and volcano location data for students to plot.

slides.text: When plates CONVERGE (push together), three things can happen: (1) Ocean plate meets continent — the denser ocean plate subducts (dives under), creating volcanoes and deep trenches. (2) Two ocean plates meet — one subducts, creating island arc volcanoes (like Japan). (3) Two continental plates meet — neither subducts; instead they crumple, forming mountains like the Himalayas.

The Ring of Fire circles the Pacific Ocean and contains 75% of the world's volcanoes and 90% of its earthquakes. This is NOT a coincidence — it follows the edges of the Pacific Plate. The Ring of Fire includes Japan, the Philippines, Indonesia, New Zealand, the west coasts of North and South America, and Alaska.

Earthquakes happen when plates get stuck, then suddenly slip. Energy builds up along faults (cracks where plates meet) until the rock breaks. The Richter scale measures this energy: each whole number is about 32 times more energy. A magnitude 7 earthquake releases about 1,000 times more energy than a magnitude 5.

Understanding plate tectonics saves lives. Japan builds earthquake-resistant structures. Tsunami warning systems alert coastal populations. Building codes in California require earthquake reinforcement. Science cannot prevent earthquakes, but it CAN help us prepare and build safer communities.

slides.prompt: Map and analyze: (1) Plot 15 major earthquake and 15 major volcano locations on a blank world map using different colored dots. (2) Overlay your plot with tectonic plate boundaries. What pattern do you see? (3) Draw detailed cross-section diagrams of each boundary type, labeling what happens to the plates and what features form. (4) Research one famous earthquake or volcanic eruption. Write a journal entry: What happened? What plate boundary caused it? How did people respond?

slides.text: Earthquakes and volcanoes are not random — they follow plate boundaries with remarkable precision. Understanding plate tectonics transforms these natural disasters from mysterious acts of nature into predictable consequences of a moving Earth.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain what happens at each boundary type, map the Ring of Fire, connect earthquake and volcano locations to plate boundaries, and discuss earthquake preparedness?

parent_notes: The connection between plate boundaries and natural disasters is one of the most satisfying patterns in science. Plotting earthquakes and volcanoes and seeing them line up with plate boundaries is a powerful 'aha' moment. If you live in an earthquake-prone area, this is an excellent time to review your family's emergency plan. The Richter scale's logarithmic nature (each number = 32x more energy) previews mathematical concepts they will encounter later.

title: Greek Music and Theater — The Origins of Western Drama
description: Students explore the origins of theater in ancient Greece, learning how music, dance, and storytelling combined to create dramatic performances. They examine the structure of Greek theater, the roles of chorus and actors, and the concepts of tragedy and comedy.
instructions:
1. Connect to Greek sculpture: drama was another expression of Greek artistic values.
2. Introduce Greek theater: born from religious festivals honoring Dionysus.
3. Describe the physical theater: amphitheater, orchestra, skene.
4. Explain the chorus: group singing and dancing that narrated the story.
5. Introduce the three types of plays: tragedy, comedy, and satyr play.
6. Discuss famous playwrights: Sophocles, Euripides, Aristophanes.
7. Explain masks and their function: expression visible from far away.
8. Listen to or read an excerpt from a Greek tragedy.
9. Students create simple masks representing tragic or comic characters.
10. Perform a short choral reading from a Greek play.
materials_needed: Rubber bands or sticks for masks

items: Rubber bands or sticks for masks
slides.setup_instructions: Print diagrams of Greek amphitheaters. Select age-appropriate excerpts from Greek plays. Prepare mask-making supplies: paper plates, markers, paint, and decorative materials.

slides.text: Greek theater began in Athens around 534 BC as part of festivals honoring Dionysus, god of wine and celebration. What started as hymns sung by a chorus evolved into the world's first plays. The Greeks invented tragedy, comedy, and the very concept of actors playing characters.

The Greek amphitheater was an engineering marvel. Cut into hillsides, it could seat 15,000 people. The curved shape amplified sound so well that a whisper on stage could be heard in the back row. The orchestra (circular area) held the chorus; the skene (building) was the backdrop and changing room.

The chorus was a group of 12-15 performers who sang, danced, and narrated. They were the voice of the community, commenting on the action and expressing emotions. Music was integral — plays were more like modern musicals than spoken dramas. Greek instruments included the lyre, aulos (double flute), and drums.

Tragedy explored human suffering and the consequences of pride (hubris). Comedy mocked politicians, philosophers, and social customs. Both were considered essential to a healthy democracy: tragedy built empathy; comedy kept leaders accountable. Theater was not entertainment — it was civic duty.

slides.prompt: Create and perform: (1) Make a Greek theater mask using a paper plate. Choose tragic (exaggerated sadness, fear, or anger) or comic (exaggerated happiness, surprise, or mischief). Use bold features visible from a distance. (2) Read an excerpt from a Greek play. In groups of 4-5, prepare a choral reading: speak together with expression, gesture, and rhythm. (3) Perform for the class. The audience evaluates: Could they understand the emotion? Was the chorus unified?

slides.text: Every movie, TV show, and stage play you have ever seen descends from Greek theater. The Greeks invented the ideas of actors, scripts, scenes, and dramatic structure. When you feel moved by a story on screen, you are experiencing something that began in an Athenian amphitheater 2,500 years ago.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe the structure and purpose of Greek theater, explain the role of the chorus, distinguish tragedy from comedy, and participate in a dramatic performance?

parent_notes: Greek theater connects art, music, and civics in a way that surprises many students. The mask-making activity is engaging and hands-on. The idea that theater was considered a civic duty — not just entertainment — is worth discussing. Watch a film adaptation of a Greek myth together and discuss how the storytelling traditions continue today.

title: Study Skills — Active Reading and Note-Taking Strategies
description: Students learn active reading strategies and effective note-taking techniques that will serve them through middle school and beyond. They practice annotating text, using graphic organizers, and transforming reading into learning.
instructions:
1. Discuss passive vs. active reading: the difference between looking at words and learning.
2. Introduce annotation: underlining, highlighting, and margin notes.
3. Model the SQ3R method: Survey, Question, Read, Recite, Review.
4. Practice annotating a short text about Greek democracy.
5. Introduce Cornell Notes as a note-taking system.
6. Model taking Cornell Notes from a reading passage.
7. Discuss different note-taking styles: outlines, mind maps, charts.
8. Practice converting notes into study tools: flashcards, summary paragraphs.
9. Students practice all strategies with a new reading passage.
10. Create a personal study strategy toolkit.

slides.setup_instructions: Print SQ3R strategy guides and Cornell Notes templates. Select two reading passages about ancient Greece at appropriate reading level. Have highlighters, sticky notes, and index cards ready.

slides.text: Passive reading means your eyes move across the page but your brain is not engaged. Active reading means you interact with the text: asking questions, making connections, noting important ideas. Research shows that active readers remember 50-70% more than passive readers.

SQ3R is a proven active reading method: SURVEY — skim headings, pictures, and bold words first. QUESTION — turn each heading into a question. READ — read to answer your questions. RECITE — say the answers in your own words. REVIEW — go back and check your understanding.

Cornell Notes divide your page into three sections: a narrow left column for CUE WORDS (key terms, questions), a wide right column for NOTES (details, examples), and a bottom section for a SUMMARY. After class or reading, fill in cue words and write a summary. This transforms notes into a study tool.

The best study strategy is RETRIEVAL PRACTICE: closing your notes and trying to remember what you learned. Then check. This is much more effective than re-reading. Use your Cornell Notes cues: cover the notes column, read the cue words, and try to recall the information.

slides.prompt: Practice study skills: (1) Use SQ3R on the provided reading passage about Greek democracy. Write your survey observations, questions from headings, and answers after reading. (2) Take Cornell Notes on a second passage: cue words on the left, detailed notes on the right, summary at the bottom. (3) Create 5 flashcards from your notes. (4) Retrieval practice: cover your notes, use only cue words to recall information. How much could you remember? (5) Design your personal Study Strategy Toolkit: which 3 strategies work best for you?

slides.text: Study skills are not about working harder — they are about working smarter. Active reading, Cornell Notes, and retrieval practice are research-proven strategies that successful students use. Building these habits now prepares you for the increasing demands of middle school and beyond.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student apply SQ3R to a reading passage, take Cornell Notes, convert notes into study tools, and practice retrieval as a learning strategy?

parent_notes: Study skills are one of the most valuable things a student can learn, yet they are rarely taught explicitly. Cornell Notes and SQ3R are used successfully through high school and college. Help your child practice at home: when reading a textbook chapter, model surveying the headings first, then reading for answers. The retrieval practice strategy (closing the book and trying to remember) is particularly powerful and can be practiced with any subject.

title: Complex Sentence Review — Grammar Assessment and Creative Application
description: Students demonstrate mastery of complex sentences through assessment and creative writing. They complete a grammar assessment covering subordinating conjunctions and relative clauses, then apply these skills in a creative story about ancient Greece.
instructions:
1. Warm-up: identify sentence types in a paragraph (simple, compound, complex).
2. Review subordinating conjunctions and their relationship types.
3. Review relative pronouns and comma rules.
4. Administer a grammar assessment on complex sentences.
5. Discuss common errors and clarify misunderstandings.
6. Transition to creative application: writing a short story set in ancient Greece.
7. Require use of at least 8 complex sentences in the story.
8. Students write, focusing on sentence variety and correct grammar.
9. Peer review for complex sentence use and punctuation.
10. Share stories and celebrate grammar growth.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare the grammar assessment covering complex sentence identification, combining, and punctuation. Create story planning templates with ancient Greek settings and character suggestions.

slides.text: This week you have learned two powerful tools: subordinating conjunctions (because, although, when, if) that create dependent clauses, and relative pronouns (who, which, that) that add detail. Both transform simple sentences into complex ones that express sophisticated ideas.

Quick review: Complex sentences have an independent clause and at least one dependent clause. Comma after a leading dependent clause. Non-essential relative clauses (which, who adding extra info) use commas. Essential relative clauses (that, who identifying which one) do not.

Your story should be set in ancient Greece. Choose a setting: Athens during a debate in the Assembly, Sparta during the agoge, the Olympic Games, or a voyage on the Mediterranean. Create a character who faces a challenge that requires courage, wisdom, or both.

Good stories use sentence variety for rhythm and effect. Short sentences create tension: 'The soldier drew his sword.' Complex sentences build context: 'Although the enemy outnumbered them ten to one, the Spartans, who had trained since childhood for this moment, held their ground.' Let your grammar serve your storytelling.

slides.prompt: Assessment and story: (1) Complete the grammar assessment: identify sentence types, combine sentences, apply comma rules, and correct errors. (2) Write a 2-page short story set in ancient Greece. Include: at least 8 complex sentences (underline them), at least 3 subordinating conjunctions and 3 relative pronouns, sentence variety (mix of simple, compound, and complex), and vivid description of your Greek setting. (3) Peer review: exchange stories and check for correct complex sentence structure and punctuation.

slides.text: Complex sentences are now part of your permanent writing toolkit. You can express cause, contrast, conditions, and additional details within a single sentence. This is the grammar of mature thinkers and clear communicators.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student demonstrate mastery of complex sentences on assessment, apply complex sentence structures in creative writing, maintain sentence variety, and correctly punctuate all sentence types?

parent_notes: This assessment-and-application lesson reveals how well your child has internalized complex sentence skills. The creative story should show natural use of complex sentences, not forced examples. Grammar skills that transfer to creative writing are truly learned. Save the story for your child's portfolio — comparing it to earlier writing will show clear growth.

title: Multiplication, Division, and Number Theory Review — Putting It All Together
description: Students review and connect the week's math concepts: multi-digit multiplication, long division, factors, multiples, and prime numbers. They solve problems that require selecting the right operation and applying number theory concepts.
instructions:
1. Review multiplication strategies: standard algorithm and partial products.
2. Review long division with checking.
3. Review factors, multiples, GCF, and LCM.
4. Review prime factorization and factor trees.
