5. Practice problems requiring students to choose the right operation.
6. Solve multi-step problems combining multiplication, division, and number theory.
7. Apply to Greek-themed word problems.
8. Students complete a comprehensive practice set.
9. Challenge: create a math puzzle using factors, primes, and operations.
10. Reflect on mathematical growth this week.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a comprehensive review worksheet covering all topics from the week. Include word problems, computation practice, and number theory investigations.

slides.text: This week's math topics all connect: Multiplication and division are inverse operations. Factors come from division; multiples come from multiplication. Prime factorization uses both operations. GCF and LCM build on factors and multiples. Mathematics is not a collection of separate topics — it is a connected web.

Choosing the right operation: 'How many groups of 8 can I make from 256 soldiers?' is division (256 / 8 = 32). 'If each group has 32 soldiers and there are 8 groups, how many total?' is multiplication (32 x 8 = 256). The question tells you the operation.

Multi-step problems require planning. 'You have 120 red tiles and 84 blue tiles. You want to make identical gift bags with the same number of each color. What is the maximum number of bags?' Step 1: Find GCF of 120 and 84. 120 = 2x2x2x3x5. 84 = 2x2x3x7. GCF = 12. Step 2: 120/12 = 10 red per bag. 84/12 = 7 blue per bag. Maximum 12 bags.

Mathematical thinking means asking: Does my answer make sense? Is it reasonable? Can I check it another way? These habits catch errors and build confidence. Always verify important calculations — even professionals check their work.

slides.prompt: Comprehensive review: (1) Compute: 347 x 28, 2,856 / 34, and check both. (2) Find all factors of 84 and determine if it is prime or composite. (3) Prime factorize 360 and use it to find GCF and LCM of 360 and 240. (4) Word problems: The Parthenon columns are 34 feet tall. If a scale model uses 1 inch for every 2 feet, how tall is the model column? An army of 2,400 soldiers marches in rows of 36. How many rows? (5) Create a math riddle: 'I am a two-digit number. I am composite. My prime factorization has exactly three prime factors. My digits add to 9. What am I?'

slides.text: This week you strengthened multiplication and division while discovering the hidden structure of numbers through factors, multiples, and primes. These are not just topics to check off — they are tools you will use in fractions, algebra, and beyond.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student fluently perform multi-digit multiplication and division, find factors and multiples, create prime factorizations, and apply number theory to multi-step problems?

parent_notes: This review lesson consolidates a week of important mathematical concepts. The connection between multiplication, division, factors, and primes helps students see mathematics as a coherent system rather than disconnected skills. The math riddle activity is a creative way to demonstrate understanding. If your child found certain topics challenging, extra practice this weekend will pay dividends.

title: Greek Philosophy — The Socratic Method and Philosophical Inquiry
description: Students meet the three great Greek philosophers who laid the foundation for Western thought. They explore Socratic questioning, Plato's Allegory of the Cave, and Aristotle's emphasis on observation, discovering how these thinkers still influence us today.
instructions:
1. Review Athens' cultural achievements: democracy, theater, art.
2. Introduce philosophy: 'love of wisdom' (philo + sophia).
3. Introduce Socrates: the teacher who taught by asking questions.
4. Practice the Socratic method: answering questions with questions.
5. Introduce Plato: Socrates' student who created the Academy.
6. Explore Plato's Allegory of the Cave: what is real knowledge?
7. Introduce Aristotle: Plato's student who observed the natural world.
8. Discuss how each philosopher built on the previous one's ideas.
9. Students practice philosophical inquiry on a chosen question.
10. Journal: Which philosopher's approach resonates most with you?

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare biography cards with key facts about each philosopher. Print or draw an illustration of the Allegory of the Cave. Create Socratic question prompts for student practice.

slides.text: Socrates (470-399 BC) never wrote anything down. He taught by asking questions, forcing people to examine their own beliefs. 'The unexamined life is not worth living,' he said. His method annoyed powerful Athenians, who accused him of corrupting the youth. He was sentenced to death and drank hemlock rather than recant his beliefs.

Plato (428-348 BC), Socrates' student, founded the Academy — one of the first universities. His Allegory of the Cave imagines prisoners chained in a cave, seeing only shadows on a wall. They think the shadows are reality. When one escapes and sees the sun, he realizes the shadows were illusions. Plato asked: Are we seeing reality or only shadows?

Aristotle (384-322 BC), Plato's student, took a different approach. While Plato looked to abstract ideals, Aristotle observed the real world: classifying animals, studying politics, analyzing logic. He tutored young Alexander the Great and wrote about everything from physics to poetry. His method of observation became the foundation of science.

Three approaches to knowledge: Socrates — question everything to discover truth. Plato — look beyond appearances to find deeper reality. Aristotle — observe the world carefully and classify what you find. All three are still used today: in courts (questioning), mathematics (abstract reasoning), and science (observation).

slides.prompt: Philosophical inquiry: (1) Practice the Socratic method: In pairs, discuss 'What makes something fair?' One partner answers while the other asks only questions (never states opinions). Switch roles. (2) Allegory of the Cave: Draw or describe a modern version. What 'shadows' might people mistake for reality today? (3) Aristotle's method: Observe one object in the room for 5 minutes. Describe everything you notice. Classify it by material, function, and origin. (4) Journal: Which philosopher's approach — questioning, abstract thinking, or observation — most matches how YOU learn best?

slides.text: Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle created a chain of wisdom: the teacher who questioned, the student who imagined, and his student who observed. Their ideas shaped Western civilization for 2,500 years and still influence how we think, learn, and argue today.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe each philosopher's key ideas and methods, practice Socratic questioning, interpret the Allegory of the Cave, and connect Greek philosophical approaches to modern thinking?

parent_notes: Greek philosophy can be wonderfully engaging for upper elementary students because it asks big questions they are naturally curious about: What is real? What is fair? How do we know what we know? The Socratic method is particularly fun to practice — try it at dinner. The Allegory of the Cave discussion can connect to media literacy: are we seeing reality or curated versions of it? These conversations build critical thinking skills.

title: Earth Science Review — Plate Tectonics and Earth's Dynamic Surface
description: Students synthesize their understanding of plate tectonics by reviewing all key concepts and conducting a hands-on investigation. They model plate interactions, analyze real seismic data, and connect Earth science to geography.
instructions:
1. Review Earth's layers and the concept of floating plates.
2. Review evidence for continental drift.
3. Review the three types of plate boundaries and their effects.
4. Discuss how plate tectonics connects to other Earth systems.
5. Conduct a hands-on plate boundary model activity.
6. Analyze a set of earthquake data: plot locations and identify patterns.
7. Discuss how plate tectonics shapes geography over time.
8. Connect plate tectonics to Greek geography: why Greece has earthquakes.
9. Students complete a plate tectonics concept map.
10. Reflect on how scientific theories develop from evidence.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare plate tectonics model supplies: graham crackers (continental crust), frosting (mantle), and wax paper (ocean floor). Print earthquake data sets. Have concept map templates ready.

slides.text: Review: Earth's crust is broken into about 15 major plates floating on the semi-liquid mantle. These plates move slowly (1-10 cm/year) due to convection currents in the mantle. Where plates meet, we get earthquakes, volcanoes, and mountain building.

The graham cracker model: Frosting represents the mantle. Graham crackers represent crustal plates. Push two crackers together — one overrides the other (subduction at convergent boundary). Pull them apart — frosting oozes up (new crust at divergent boundary). Slide them past each other — they catch and jerk (transform boundary).

Greece sits near the boundary between the African and Eurasian plates. This is why Greece has frequent earthquakes and volcanic islands like Santorini. The geography you studied — the mountains, islands, and peninsulas of Greece — was shaped by millions of years of plate movement.

Plate tectonics is a scientific THEORY — not a guess, but a well-supported explanation backed by overwhelming evidence. Wegener proposed continental drift in 1912 and was ridiculed. But as evidence accumulated — seafloor spreading, magnetic striping, earthquake patterns — the theory became accepted. Science advances through evidence, patience, and sometimes courage.

slides.prompt: Investigate and synthesize: (1) Use graham crackers and frosting to model all three boundary types. Observe what happens at each. Draw and label your observations. (2) Plot the provided earthquake data on a world map. Do your plots match plate boundaries? (3) Create a plate tectonics concept map connecting: plates, boundaries, earthquakes, volcanoes, mountains, evidence, and scientists. Show how all concepts relate. (4) Journal: How does scientific thinking differ from other ways of knowing? What role does evidence play?

slides.text: Plate tectonics demonstrates how science works at its best: observations lead to hypotheses, evidence accumulates, and understanding grows. The ground beneath you is alive with motion — building mountains, opening oceans, and reshaping the planet on a timescale beyond human experience.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student model plate boundary interactions, analyze earthquake data for patterns, create a concept map connecting plate tectonic concepts, and explain how scientific theories develop from evidence?

parent_notes: The graham cracker plate model is a beloved science activity that makes abstract concepts tangible. The concept map synthesizes the week's learning into a visual web. The discussion about how scientific theories develop is valuable metacognition. If your child is intrigued by plate tectonics, explore earthquake and volcano resources online — the USGS has real-time earthquake maps that are fascinating.

title: Greek Mosaic Art — Creating Patterns from Pieces
description: Students explore the ancient art of mosaic, learning how Greek and Roman artists created stunning images from tiny pieces of stone, glass, and ceramic. They design and create their own mosaics using paper tiles, connecting art to mathematics through geometric patterns.
instructions:
1. Connect to Greek sculpture and theater: mosaics were another Greek art form.
2. Introduce mosaic history: from simple pebble floors to elaborate pictorial art.
3. Examine famous Greek mosaics: the Alexander Mosaic, geometric floor patterns.
4. Discuss materials: tesserae (small tiles) of stone, glass, and ceramic.
5. Analyze geometric patterns in Greek mosaics: symmetry, repetition, borders.
6. Connect to math: symmetry, area, and geometric shapes in mosaic design.
7. Demonstrate paper mosaic technique: cutting and arranging small squares.
8. Students design their mosaic pattern on graph paper.
9. Create a paper mosaic using the planned design.
10. Display and discuss the mathematical patterns in each mosaic.
materials_needed: Colored construction paper (pre-cut squares or for cutting)
Cardboard or heavy paper for base

items: Colored construction paper (pre-cut squares or for cutting)
Cardboard or heavy paper for base
slides.setup_instructions: Print photographs of Greek mosaics showing both geometric and pictorial designs. Pre-cut small squares of colored construction paper (1 cm x 1 cm) or have scissors available. Prepare cardboard bases for mosaics.

slides.text: Mosaics are among the oldest art forms, dating back to 3000 BC. Greek artists perfected the technique, creating elaborate floor and wall decorations from tiny pieces called tesserae. The most famous Greek mosaic, the Alexander Mosaic from Pompeii, contains about 1.5 million tiny tiles forming a battle scene.

Greek mosaics showcase mathematical concepts: SYMMETRY — designs that mirror on one or more axes. TESSELLATION — shapes that fit together without gaps. GEOMETRIC PATTERNS — borders of repeating shapes. PROPORTION — the relationship between different sections of the design.

Mosaic technique requires patience and planning. Each tiny piece must be placed deliberately. The spaces between tesserae (called grout lines) are part of the design. Color choices create depth: lighter colors for highlights, darker for shadows. The limitations of the medium — small square pieces — force creative problem-solving.

Plan before you build. Use graph paper to design your mosaic: each square represents one tile. Start with the border (Greek mosaics always had decorative borders). Then plan the central design: a geometric pattern, a Greek key border, a simple image, or an abstract design. Choose your color scheme: 3-5 colors work best.

slides.prompt: Create a Greek-inspired mosaic: (1) On graph paper, design your mosaic (at least 8 x 8 squares). Include a decorative border and a central design. Use colored pencils to plan your color scheme. (2) Cut small squares of colored paper or use pre-cut tesserae. (3) Glue your tesserae onto the cardboard base following your design. Leave small gaps between pieces for grout lines. (4) Write a brief artist's statement: What Greek design elements did you use? What mathematical concepts appear in your mosaic?

slides.text: Mosaic art proves that beauty can be built from small, simple pieces carefully arranged. This is true in art, in mathematics, and in life. The patience and precision required for mosaics are the same qualities that built the Parthenon, wrote Greek philosophy, and created democracy.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain mosaic history and technique, identify mathematical concepts in mosaic design, plan a design on graph paper, and execute a paper mosaic with geometric elements?

parent_notes: Mosaic art is wonderfully meditative and connects art to mathematics naturally. The graph paper planning phase develops spatial reasoning and geometric thinking. If your child enjoys this, explore real mosaic kits available at craft stores — working with actual tiles is a wonderful next step. Visit a museum or search online for Greek mosaics to see the incredible detail achievable with tiny tiles.
